abstract.para: The topic covers switching of modes using the setenforce command and by changing the permanent configuration.

topic.para: You can switch between the enforcing and permissive modes by using the setenforce command. Alternatively, you can switch between all SELinux modes by editing the /etc/selinux/config configuration file. Changes performed by the setenforce command are valid only until the next reboot. For persistent changes of the SELinux mode, edit the /etc/selinux/config configuration file.

note.title: Relabeling your system after switching from the disabled mode
note.para: If you disable SELinux on your system and then enable it later, make sure that you relabel your system. When SELinux is disabled, and you perform changes to your file system, the changes are not reflected in the context anymore (for example, new files do not have any context). Therefore, you need to relabel your system by using the restorecon command, using the autorelabel boot parameter, or by creating a file that will trigger relabeling on the next boot.
